notes:
1. Average Value of a Sinusoid

The mathematical average value of a function $f(t)$ over an interval from $t_1$ to $t_2$ is given by $\frac{1}{t_2-t_1}\int_{t_1}^{t_2} f(t) dt$.

For a sinusoidal AC waveform, the average value over one full cycle is zero. This is because the positive half-cycle is identical in shape and size to the negative half-cycle, and they cancel each other out.

2. Average Value of a Rectified Waveform

In electronics, the term "average value" often refers to the average of a rectified signal, which is what a DC voltmeter would measure. This is found by averaging the absolute value of the waveform.

  • Full-Wave Rectified Sine Wave: The average value is the average of one half-cycle.
    • $$V_{avg} = \frac{2V_p}{\pi} \approx 0.637 V_p$$
  • Half-Wave Rectified Sine Wave: The average is taken over the full cycle, but one half is zero.
    • $$V_{avg} = \frac{V_p}{\pi} \approx 0.318 V_p$$

Unless specified otherwise, "average value" in AC circuits typically refers to the full-wave rectified average.

solvedExamples.question: What is the average value of a pure sinusoidal voltage waveform over one complete cycle?
solvedExamples.explanation: The area under the curve for the positive half-cycle is equal and opposite to the area under the curve for the negative half-cycle. Over one full period, the net area is zero, so the average value is zero.

solvedExamples.question: A sinusoidal AC voltage has a peak value of 170 V. What is its full-wave rectified average value?
solvedExamples.explanation:
The average value for a full-wave rectified sine wave is given by $V_{avg} = \frac{2V_p}{\pi}$.
$V_{avg} = \frac{2(170 \text{ V})}{\pi} \approx 0.637 \times 170 \text{ V} \approx 108.3$ V.
